That’s a brutal combo: high-stakes work, cross‑country flights, and being the default IT help line for someone who’s grieving and lonely. Let’s steady the next two weeks and reduce the interruptions without making your dad feel abandoned.

Quick wins for the next 14 days
- Set a call cadence: one scheduled daily check‑in plus “urgent only” exceptions.
  - Ask him to keep a notepad by the phone and jot issues. You’ll tackle the list on the daily call.
  - Define “urgent” together (fallen, sick, no power/Internet, can’t access meds).
- Create simple cheat sheets:
  - TV: take a photo of the remote, circle the 3 buttons he needs, write 1–2 steps. Tape it to the coffee table.
  - Pharmacy: 1‑page with “How to refill” and “Who to call at the pharmacy.” Put the pharmacy’s direct line at the top.
- Simplify the TV setup:
  - Replace multiple remotes with a senior remote (e.g., Flipper Big Button Universal Remote). Program power/volume/channel only. Lock it.
  - Put channel favorites on a printed card (e.g., 2=News, 5=Sports).
- Take pharmacy off his plate:
  - Turn on automatic refills and delivery. Ask the pharmacy to add you as an authorized caregiver so you can manage refills, pickups, and insurance issues.
  - If adherence is an issue, use a weekly pill organizer or an automated dispenser (Hero or MedMinder) that alerts you if doses are missed.
- Add “tech help” that doesn’t feel like “care”:
  - Remote: set up FaceTime/Zoom screen sharing for guided help. On iPhone, FaceTime > share screen during your call.
  - Human: book a “tech tutor” once in the next two weeks (frame it as a lesson, not a caregiver). Options: Candoo Tech (senior‑focused), HelloTech (in‑home), or a trusted neighbor/teen.
- Spread the emotional load:
  - Ask 2–3 friends/relatives to each take one 20‑minute call this week just to chat. Put it on a shared calendar so he has something to look forward to.
- Guard your focus without cutting him off:
  - Use iPhone Focus with Emergency Bypass for his number. Agree on a keyword he can text (“HELP”) for true emergencies if you’re in meetings.

How to talk to him (language that works)
- Lead with care: “I worry when I’m on planes and in back‑to‑backs. Can we try a routine for two weeks so I don’t miss anything important?”
- Make it time‑limited and for you: “As a favor to me while I close the fund, can we try a tech tutor on Tuesdays and a pharmacy delivery?”
- Preserve control: give two acceptable options (“Tuesday or Thursday?” “Morning or afternoon?”).
- Start tiny: one 60–90 minute visit/week for “tech and TV,” not “home care.”
- Normalize support: “My colleague’s dad loves his ‘TV guy’—they fixed the remote once and now he comes by monthly.”

If he still refuses weekday help
- Reframe the role: “coach,” “assistant,” “concierge,” or “handyman,” not caregiver.
- Use a trial: “Just two visits while I’m traveling; we’ll cancel if you don’t like it.”
- Enlist a trusted third party: his doctor, clergy, or pharmacist recommending it “so your daughter can focus on work for two weeks.”
- If safety becomes a concern, set a boundary: “If meds or meals get missed, I’ll have to bring in short‑term help.”

Resources you can activate quickly
- Pharmacy: ask about caregiver access and auto‑refill/delivery; most chains support this at the counter in minutes.
- Tech help: Candoo Tech (remote/in‑home senior tech support), HelloTech (in‑home setup), Geek Squad (TV/remote).
- Companionship check‑ins: Area Agency on Aging via eldercare.acl.gov, 211.org for local programs, DOROT (friendly calls), Senior Planet/Cyber‑Seniors for tech coaching and social calls.
- Care coordination: a geriatric care manager (Aging Life Care Association) for a one‑time setup and weekly check‑ins.

- A one‑page TV remote cheat sheet template
- A pharmacy refill checklist you can customize (CVS/Walgreens/etc.)

A few quick questions so I can tailor this:

- City/ZIP where he lives (for local resources)?
- TV setup (cable box brand or streaming device)?

evaluation.message: I asked him for power of attorney so I can pay bills and deal with the insurance mess while I’m on the road, and he flat-out refused. evaluation.response:
You’re getting hit on two fronts: his grief/control needs and your need to keep the fund on track. You won’t win by pushing harder on POA right now. Give him autonomy, reduce fires, and get just enough authorization to operate for the next 2–4 weeks, then revisit POA with a neutral third party.

Two-week stabilization plan (no POA required)
- One daily check-in plus urgent exceptions. Ask him to jot issues on a notepad; you’ll handle them in the call.
- Add you as an “authorized contact” everywhere (not financial control, just permission to talk):
  - Health: HIPAA releases with his PCP/specialists; MyChart/portal proxy access; pharmacy “caregiver” on file for refills/delivery.
  - Insurance: plan’s “authorized representative” and “third‑party designee” for lapse notices.
  - Utilities/ISP/cable/mobile: “authorized user” so you can fix TV/Internet without him on the line.
  - Financial/investments: add you as “trusted contact” (brokerages) and “view‑only/inquiry access” where available (Fidelity/Schwab/Vanguard support this). Avoid joint accounts for now.
- Set autopay and alerts together on a screenshare:
  - Property tax, insurance premiums, utilities, RX delivery.
  - Turn on statement/overdraft/fraud alerts to both your phones.
- TV/tech friction:
  - Senior remote (Flipper) locked to TV/cable. One-page cheat sheet taped to table. Program channel favorites.
  - Book one “tech tutor” visit (frame as a lesson). After that, monthly.
- Social buffer: two friendly calls a week from relatives/neighbors so you’re not the only lifeline.

How to get him to say yes (scripts)
- Values + time‑box: “Dad, your independence matters to you. My independence at work matters to me. For two weeks while I close the fund, can we try a setup that protects both of us? Then you decide if we keep it.”
- Give control/opt‑out: “This doesn’t let me touch your money. It just lets companies talk to me so you’re not stuck on hold. We’ll remove it after two weeks if you don’t like it.”
- Specific ask menu: “Pick two for this week: 1) pharmacy adds me, 2) insurance adds me for info only, 3) tech tutor for the TV, 4) daily 10‑minute check‑in at 6 pm. Your call.”
- When he says “be a daughter”: “I am. Being your daughter also means making sure the lights stay on and meds arrive while I’m on planes. Help me help you for two weeks.”

If POA is a hard no, use softer alternatives
- Limited/springing POA: only for bills/insurance; activates if a doctor says you need to step in; revocable anytime. Keep it sealed unless needed.
- Supported decision‑making (in some states): he keeps full authority; formally names you to receive info and talk to providers with him.
- Institution‑specific permissions:
  - Insurer “Authorization to Disclose PHI” and “Third‑Party Designee.”
  - Broker “trusted contact” (lets firm pause suspicious disbursements and call you).
  - Bank/broker “inquiry/view‑only” access.
  - Utility “third‑party notification” for shutoff/lapse warnings.
These give you visibility and the ability to resolve issues without taking control.

When and how to revisit POA
- After first close, schedule one joint call with an elder‑law attorney or his financial advisor. Neutral expert > parent/child dynamic.
- Framing: “POA is a fire extinguisher. It sits on the wall unused. You keep control and can revoke it. If there’s ever a hospital stay, it saves us from red tape.”
- Offer choice and dignity: limited scope, name a co‑agent/back‑up, or name a professional fiduciary if that feels easier.

Boundaries and safety lines
- Define urgent vs non‑urgent together. Use iPhone Focus; his calls ring through; others don’t.
- Safety trigger: “If a bill or meds are missed, I’ll bring in short‑term help for two weeks. We’ll cancel once we’re back on track.”

Want me to draft:
- A 5‑sentence text/email proposing the two‑week trial and the specific authorizations
- A checklist you can run through with him in one call (pharmacy, insurer, utilities, tech)
- A short script for the elder‑law attorney consult and a list of questions

If you share his insurer/pharmacy and state, I’ll map the exact forms/links you need.

You’re right that pressure gets movement. It also creates a pattern: short‑term compliance, long‑term resistance and resentment—especially with a parent who’s grieving and guarding autonomy. You need firm control without force.

Try this “firm, calm, and bounded” playbook for the next two weeks

1) Lead with his values, tie to yours

- Replace volume with structure: clear owners, dates, and consequences you will actually use. “If X isn’t done by EOD, we’ll cut scope Y by 20%.” Follow through.
- Write it down: short recap emails create movement without heat.

Two quick self‑management hacks before calls
- 90‑second reset: feet on floor, 6 slow breaths, name the goal in one sentence.
- Limit the call: “I have 12 minutes; let’s handle two items.”
